The State of California granted Pamela Courson Morrison a widow's allowance until the will in which Jim Morrison left everything to her was able to finish probate. The State of California based that judgment on the paperwork that accompanied the common law marriage between Morrison and Courson-Morrison in Colorado in the mid Sixties.

Since Pamela Courson Morrison wasn't present when Morrison died, I think it rather narrow minded to blame her for Morrison's death. The only reason Pamela blamed herself was because when she returned to the apartment they shared, hours after his death, Pamela assumed it was her drugs Jim sampled.

Where Morrison actually got hold of the drugs that killed him is still undecided. However, one need not look too far to know who killed Jim Morrison. It was Jim Morrison.

ETUI bogus? It might be archaic, and borrowed from French, but it's a legit word. For example, here's citation from Gilbert & Sullivan's "Princess Ida," Act II, showing that it was in use in England in 1884, and whenever "Princess Ida" is produced ever since:

MELISSA: ...why, see,
Here is an étui dropped by one of them (picking up an etui.)
Containing scissors, needles, and –
BLANCHE: (opening it) Cigars!
Why, these are men! And you knew this, you minx!

To Flavius Aetius,

Such a disingenuous comment. So what that Obama is Black? How many muslims lead Europe? How any Roma (Gypsies) etc. Nor can Europeans scoff at class divisions or other bigotry.

The middle class European is as staid, and bound to certain concepts as any other. There are still titled nobility. And Spain? Such a short way from Franco, trying to claim superiority?

If I didn't know any Europeans, I might believe this "americans are a joke' nonsense and be upset. But I do know them, and they no more regard America as a joke, than I regard Europe as a joke.

Being middle class does not mean we are all babbits, either here or there. Live in Spain if you wish. I hear there is much that is lovely, but spare us this errant nonsense.

What am I?  I am in my 50's (although I don't feel like it).  I receive Social Security Disability benefits for an illness that will never be cured.  I stay on it because I would never be able to afford my medication otherwise.  I am forced to live in other states, small cities, where my SSD will cover my rent and a little bit more.  I could never afford to live in my hometown, NYC, anymore.  And yet, I suffer because I am not surrounded by the highly-educated, sophisticated, cultured people that I am used to.  I am well-travelled, and have lived abroad, well-read, speak 3 foreign languages (although not fluently); I miss the museums, The Kennedy Center, Lincoln Center, The Anjelica, The E St Cinema, seminars. lectures, dinner parties. I don't have a college degree although one would never know it after 10 minutes in my company.  I am forced to live in socio-economic areas that I don't belong in, where people are OBESE, white trash, red-necks, shop at WalMart and the supermarket in their pajamas and slippers - no kidding.  Oh, and I don't own a car.  Sold it 3 1/2 years ago because I couldn't afford the payment anymore.  I'm not stuck though.  I will move to another city/state that is cheaper to live in and hopefully not like where I am now.  So, what am I considered?  Middle class?  Lower class?  Working class?

As a recipient of a public pension I can tell you my family was made to fund that pension and as a young family it was hard to see the money leave our checks during the '70s, '80s and '90s as we labored hard for never more than a 2% increase in wages (if we actually received a increase _ many years we didn't). Also there were no Christmas bonuses and profit sharing _ things many of our friends in private business expected and received. The last 30 years were not the greatest for middle class families. Remember 15 percent 30-year mortgages? Well, I do. After graduating from college in the mid-70s it was a rocky flight into an adulthood that featured a secure retirement. I am now thankful for that pension and am hopeful we don't slip into poverty.

Jim, you've correctly said it all about today's wonderful puzzle so allow me to dwell for a bit on your time at Wordplay and point out that, while you have calmly guided this ship from the start, there have been at least two occasions when you seemed to rise above and beyond anyone's expectations.

The first of my memory came when you wrote a brilliant review of Michael Sharp's first Times puzzle last August, in the character of Sharp's nom de puzzle, Rex Parker; it was wordplay at its finest and a notable piece of humor.

Then, tonight, you have clearly warmed to the Double K offering of Messrs. Kaskel and Kantor and it has spawned the most extensive review of your tenure and an unequivocal, (deserved), 5 star rating which is, perhaps, a first for you as well.

From day one of Wordplay, you've been a steady hand in letting a sometimes rambunctious flock get its views expressed and you've been an honest broker in maintaining and promoting civil discourse.

Thank you and Godspeed in your next challenge.

some America's "middle class" can't secure the Very Basic Human Need: 3 meals everyday.
This is logically invalid and materially false.
Point being this, we Americans collectively can't deceiving ourself indefinitely: such as "land of opprotunites", " You can be anything you want to be in America"

I was born in 1943. In my teens I recognized that societies come and go, that resources were not infinite, that someday everything would runout. I also saw that I was living in the luckiest time possible: huge advances in medicine, education, technology, social science were rampant. But I often wondered when it would all end and if it would happen before I died. I'm thankful for what I have. Nothing is guaranteed in life. The reason I bring all this up is that the very fact that a debate is occuring about a definition of middle class shows me that many people do not (want to??) understand or want to accept their position in life. Face it, none of us have any claim on anything, let alone middle class status. My happiness was and is not based on any of that. Chuang Tzu said it best for me: "Happiness is never found until you stop looking for it".

The demarcations between upper, middle, and lower classes seem simple enough to me. Upper class is where you don't have to work to live, with the attendant consequences. Middle class is where you have to work, again with the attendant consequences, but you are comfortable, in various senses of the word. Lower class is where even though you work, you are not comfortable. However, you are not necessarily unhappy. You may even be happier than an upper class person.

I might agree, if the writer qualified her three hallmarks of a secure middle class life. I'll repeat them here and comment. You'll see why at the end.

(1) the ability to earn a living through stable, steady and productive work.

Meaningful work - producing something tangible, or working toward the production of some tangible good or service that is knowable in the process of doing the work. Being free of most physical and mental disabilities from the work done, including travel to and from and for work.

(2) the ability to form stable marriages as the basis of child-rearing and family life

A middle-class existence is only for some, during a limited time in their lives, after childhood and before old age. Home making is paramount to both members of a couple, gender roles and different sexes are not. Children are optional. Older age excludes many from a middle-class existence, regardless of income, or net worth. 'Family life' involves all members of a household, simultaneously, doing work in the home that maintains the household.

(3) the ability to save and to build assets for future goals and for giving to others.

Only the physically and mentally-abled stay in the middle class for a time in their lives and so long as they actually give to others during that time, not in old age, not just at death, not in 'volunteer' work. Leaving some assets for anyone at death and receiving the same, does not qualify the survivor as achieving a hallmark of securing a middle-class existence on their own. Personal insurance is no substitute for achieving middle-class status.

The middle class is a social network of people who enjoy working and being known as 'middle-class.'

A middle-class existence is still a fading dream for most. A lot of us currently are having a nightmare.

I grew up upper middle class and remained middle class, based on income, until I became disabled and am now poor. I live in an income-restricted (aka low income) complex, and do not identify with my neighbors whatsoever.

Here are some of the differences: They smoke cigarettes. They do not separate their garbage for recycling. They do not pick up their dogs' poop (the dogs are primarily pit bulls). And their children do not wear helmets when riding bicycles.

There's class, and then there's economic class. The latter may change based on changing definitions, but if one truly has class, a change in economic circumstances won't take it away.

Poor, of course!

The problem is that many confuse "money" with "means."  I grew up in a lower middle class home and neighborhood (20-25K yearly income, 1970s reference point).  But my family's "means" boosted our standard of living considerably.  My father and his brothers-in-law built most of the family home (brick vs most homes on street being shingle; hardwood floors thorough out).  A family friend who did plaster work threw in a gorgeous crown moulding in the LR that's unlike anything I've seen since.   We had a junk of a car, but I lived two blocks from my junior/senior high school so I rarely needed it.  From 7th through 12th grades I walked to school and participated in onsite sports, band, school newspaper, yearly drama productions, rifle team, ROTC, Spanish club, Boy's State; you name it (I couldn't have fit in anything more if it were offered on a silver platter).  My mom was a housewife so we struggled on one salary, but because she could volunteer as a chaperone for all the school outings, I didn't need to pay the fee.  I got new clothes yearly at a very humble clothing store, but never gave a hoot about clothes anyway (quickly changing into jeans and a t-shirt as soon as I could).  I had pets, a large extended family for great holiday get togethers and when it was time for college, my straight A GPA and SATs + modest family income = full tuition scholarship to a top 10 college (US News & World Report).  By objective measures, I was lower middle class - definitely.  When you factor in "means" I did better than many with family incomes 3X higher.

A large middle class is truly an outstanding human achievement, but Whitehead gives too much emphasis to some factors (individual effort, Anglo-Saxon) and not enough to historical process and the accumulated energies and wisdom of human societies over many centuries --stretching back at least to the Sumerians --for which we in 2010 can give thanks. The middle class emerged in Dutch and British societies, among others, with the nascent American nation along as a rider (and the neighboring Irish somewhat rudely excluded until recently).  Liberal thought has done much to "liberate" us from want and fear --and risk.  Whitehead fails to recognize the important role of risk-sharing and insurance mechanisms --from joint-stock companies to the poor laws--which help push forward the progress of the industrial revolution and the emergence of a strong and growing middle class.  Indeed, one of the most important characteristics of being middle class is that one "endures" without tipping into disaster and poverty or death.  Being middle class means being (mostly) safe -- a legacy more precious that great wealth or kingdoms.  It is that legacy which we hope for all Americans, and indeed for all of humanity.

I am working class. Yes I have a B.A. degree and make what would be considered a good income anywhere outside of NY. But I'm no fool. If I lost my job I would be up sh*t's creek. That makes me a working person. Period.

Let's not blame middle class envy for the recent (decades long) reduction in taxation for the wealthy. The fact is that so much money is at the top of the private sector that the government can essentially be bought by the highest bidder.  The middle class have very little voice in government anymore.

The difference is pocket money, what you do with it. The pocket money payed for a family cars and a place to live. That is where the real money is a little at a time. pay check to pay check one day at a time year after year. Just being content made every thing real every moment of every day.
I know people who made four times more money than me and will always be broke, always wanting the real money. It don't come easy. You know it just ain't easy.

Let's face the facts. Globalization has changed everything. It boggles my mind to consistently hear arguments for more government spending, more unions, and more bureaucracies on the one hand and more corporate giveaways, more bank bailouts, and less regulation on the other hand.  Why cannot we simply value work and productivity? As long as we don't value real work, real education , and consider a degree in sociology to be equivalent or more valuable than a degree in Physical Chemistry then there is no other way for us to go but down. We are turning into either an army of disgruntled workers or business analysts or worse yet project leads or managers. How long does it take to become one?  Two weeks. This was what we have been paddling to the rest of developing world when we have been exporting our hard earned skills and manufacturing jobs.  Now they have caught up to our tricks. It has been said that 9 out of 10  Chinese top leaders have engineering degrees. On the other extreme, our politicians only pay lip service to the issue. Our only salvation is to put to use  our excellent higher education institutions, particularly the scientific ones,  when we still have them.
